DataElement.preferredName: Functional Magnetic Resonance Imaging Brain Connectivity and Activation Magnetic Resonance Imaging Type
DataElement.preferredDefinition: A noninvasive tool used to observe functioning in the brain or other organs by detecting changes in chemical composition, blood flow, or both._An organ composed of grey and white matter containing billions of neurons that is the center for intelligence and reasoning. It is protected by the bony cranium._The ability to make and maintain a connection between two or more points in a telecommunications systems._To cause something to start or to stimulate activity._Imaging that uses radiofrequency waves and a strong magnetic field rather than x-rays to provide amazingly clear and detailed pictures of internal organs and tissues. The technique is valuable for the diagnosis of many pathologic conditions, including cancer, heart and vascular disease, stroke, and joint and musculoskeletal disorders._Type; a subdivision of a particular kind of thing.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: A noninvasive tool used to observe functioning in the brain or other organs by detecting changes in chemical composition, blood flow, or both.

Concepts.definition: The principle of functional MRI imaging is to take a series of images of an organ in quick succession and to statistically analyze the images for differences among them.  Most commonly used in studies of brain function.

Property.preferredDefinition: An organ composed of grey and white matter containing billions of neurons that is the center for intelligence and reasoning. It is protected by the bony cranium.:The ability to make and maintain a connection between two or more points in a telecommunications systems.:To cause something to start or to stimulate activity.

Concepts.definition: An organ composed of grey and white matter containing billions of neurons that is the center for intelligence and reasoning. It is protected by the bony cranium.
The ability to make and maintain a connection between two or more points in a telecommunications systems.
To cause something to start or to stimulate activity.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: Events, people, materials and activities uniquely defined by medical imaging.
ConceptualDomain.origin: DICOM:Digital Imaging and Communications in Medicine

ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: Imaging that uses radiofrequency waves and a strong magnetic field rather than x-rays to provide amazingly clear and detailed pictures of internal organs and tissues. The technique is valuable for the diagnosis of many pathologic conditions, including cancer, heart and vascular disease, stroke, and joint and musculoskeletal disorders._Type; a subdivision of a particular kind of thing.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A T2-weighted MRI image that has the advantage of separating white-matter lesions from cerebrospinal fluid-like lesions. A T2-weighted image is a magnetic resonance image where the contrast is predominantly dependent on T2, and is a sequence that provides sensitivity to pathologic processes through changes in water content.

A type of perfusion imaging that uses the serial acquisition of MR images to track the entrance of diffusible contrast agents into tissue over time. DCE relies on T2 changes. Physiological parameters can be extracted that relate to, for example, tissue perfusion and microvascular vessel wall permeability (denoted by the parameter Ktrans), and extracellular volume fraction (denoted by ve).

A type of perfusion imaging that uses the serial acquisition of MR images to track the entrance of diffusible contrast agents into tissue over time. DCE relies on T1 changes. Physiological parameters can be extracted that relate to, for example, tissue perfusion and microvascular vessel wall permeability (denoted by the parameter Ktrans), and extracellular volume fraction (denoted by ve).

A technique which basically exploits the magnetic properties of protons using their chemical shifts. In the medical application (MRSI), it is one of the MR 
techniques, which measures the other metabolites' signals in brain after supressing the water signal.

A method of observing the haemodynamic response related to neural activity in the brain (i.e. which areas of the brain are active at any given time) using the difference in magnetic susceptibility between oxyhemoglobin and 
deoxyhemoglobin.
A small-flip-angle gradient**-recalled echo* *sequence with a 3D Fourier transform acquisition technique that has been implemented with a 180Â° inversion recovery preparation pulse.

Diffusion tensor imaging enables diffusion to be measured 
in multiple directions and the fractional anisotropy in each direction to be calculated for each voxel. This enables researchers to make brain maps of fiber directions to examine the connectivity of different regions in the brain.

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Spin Lattice Relaxation Time post Gadolinium

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Spin Lattice Relaxation Time post Gadolinium
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: This is the time to reduce the difference between the longitudinal magnetization and its equilibrium magnetization by a factor of e after the administering of gadolinium.

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Spin Lattice Relaxation Time pre Gadolinium

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Spin Lattice Relaxation Time pre Gadolinium
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Time to reduce the difference between the longitudinal magnetization and its equilibrium magnetization by a factor of 'e' before the administering of gadolinium. In general, T_1 governs the rate of recovery of the longitudinal magnetization.
The time to reduce the transverse magnetization by a factor of 'e' and is always less than or equal to T_1.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: Events, people, materials and activities uniquely defined by medical imaging.
ConceptualDomain.origin: DICOM:Digital Imaging and Communications in Medicine

RepresentationTerm.preferredDefinition: Imaging that uses radiofrequency waves and a strong magnetic field rather than x-rays to provide amazingly clear and detailed pictures of internal organs and tissues. The technique is valuable for the diagnosis of many pathologic conditions, including cancer, heart and vascular disease, stroke, and joint and musculoskeletal disorders. :Type; a subdivision of a particular kind of thing.

Concepts.definition: Imaging that uses radiofrequency waves and a strong magnetic field rather than x-rays to provide detailed pictures of internal organs and tissues. The technique is valuable for the diagnosis of many pathologic conditions, including cancer, heart and vascular disease, stroke, and joint and musculoskeletal disorders.
Something distinguishable as an identifiable class based on common qualities.
